original_title: Sri Lankan migrant workers for Japan civil aviation sector
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s workers will be able to work in the Japanese civil aviation sector from next year, the labour minister has said.

“Excited to share that starting March next year, we’re opening doors for Sri Lankans to work in Japan’s Civil Aviation sector,” Manusha Nanayakkara, Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment said on X (twitter).

After a foreign exchange crisis last year, the Sri Lankan government, and Nanayakkara in particular, have been in a drive to increase foreign remittances through its migrant workers, a key source of forex for the country.
Pilots of state-run SriLankan Airlines have been leaving the country as doctors are leaving the country for higher salaries Aviation Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva said earlier.
“They get the training from us, get our flying hours and they leave for higher salaries,” Minister de Silva told parliament in June.

Nearly 60 pilots have left SriLankan Airlines in the last 12 months and the national carrier has recruited a number of new cadet pilots to face the shortage, SriLankan officials said in September. (Colombo/Dec8/2023)
